awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Building a Pipeline to STEM Careers in South Central Los Angeles Through Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
Building a Pipeline to Science, Technology, Engineering and Math (STEM) Careers in South Central Los Angeles is an effort use computational skill development as a catalyst for broader academic achievement. The work develops a year long computing seminar that serves as a complement to the Exploring Computer Science course in a high school in Los Angeles.  The seminar is robust in its attempt to address the factors that impede academic achievement of a subset of boys of color in the lower quartile of performance in mathematics.

The study operationalizes computing education as a means of igniting broader academic achievement.  The premise of the work focuses on infusing into computing instruction established techniques from the learning sciences that are effective in addressing the broader social and institutional factors that often hinder students' academic achievement. The deployment of more Exploring Computer Science (ECS) courses has not by itself mitigated some of the academic achievement gaps correlated with race and gender. This work is an attempt to develop a complement to ECS and courses like it, to serve students operating under difficult academic circumstances.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
The following are significant results from our research findings that addresses our major goals of our project:

Teacher Pedagogical Mindsets and Instructional Practices

From our classroom observations, our research findings highlight the critical pedagogical approaches of computer science teachers and how their instructional practices support the development of computational thinking skills for three cohorts of students in one South Los Angeles high school.   In our final year of the grant reporting period ((2020-2021 academic year), we discovered that opportunities to foster different student computational thinking skills in class vary from assignment to assignment; however, an emphasis on reading a logical sequence of steps and understanding algorithms remains embedded into every assignment.

Student Autonomy & Co-Constructing Knowledge

Allowing students creative freedom to design, create, and demonstrate their creative ideas is critical in making computer science more culturally relevant irrespective of a teacher's pre-existing knowledge of their students' cultural background. Along with student creative freedom, student collaboration and allowing students to share their work and ideas with other students in class is one way to ensure students can begin to see themselves and their peers as active participants in a STEM field.

Affirming Learning Environments Are Critical

Findings from the teacher interview and routine classroom observations demonstrates his care for students by affirming who they are, where they come from, and integrating their experiences into his instructional planning. Over the course of the grant, we were able to observe the ECS course and gain insights on the ways in which the teacher(s) adjusted their curriculum to meet students where they are and adjust instruction accordingly.  During this last academic year, we had to adjust our observations as schools were navigating the pandemic.  We were able to observe virtual synchronous instruction as well as participate in structured asynchronous feedback sessions between the teacher and students.

Students Connecting With Guest Speakers & Stem Industry Professionals

One of the main purposes of having guest speakers and site visits was to promote meaningful conversations for the students. During our first two years, we were happy to provide students with access to community circles, instructional support in classrooms, guest speakers from STEM industry professionals, and field trips (e.g. Google Campus, etc.).  This past year, students were able to participate in a virtual conference sponsored by I Am Tech where they had access to guest speakers from STEM industries, they applied critical thinking, problem solving, and collaborative skills through group participation. Providing access and exposure to STEM industry professionals influenced their motivation to pursue computer science. These also underscored the teachers pedagogical mindsets and belief that all students must have equitable access to computer science while also strengthening and informing his instructional practices.

Achievements 

Accepted Conference Paper Proposal

Accepted Proposal, "Shifting Pedagogically:  Examining Teacher Pedagogical Approaches And Their Instructional Practices In Developing Students Stem-Identities? that will be virtually presented at  the International Conference on Engineering, Science and Technology (IConEST) which will take place on October 21-24, 2021 in Chicago.  

This paper documents the role of teachers and their pedagogical and instructional approaches used to build STEM Identity, establish cultural awareness, and the role of exposing students to stem industry professionals can promote greater interests in students as a vehicle for promoting STEM pathways.  

 Awarded NSF Funded Research-Practice Partnership

Our work at CDAGS set the stage for our current RPP expansion efforts that will enable us to establish a vertical articulation around computational thinking and development and STEM pathways for marginalized South Los Angeles Students. The purpose of the RPP is to advance our understanding of: 1) effective models (e.g., shared planning & instruction across grade levels, near-peer mentorship) for CT student development in schools that serve predominantly low-income students of color; 2) the types of educational pathways and partnerships that can remove barriers to learning; and 3) explore how CT development can be used as a means for promoting student learning in Mathematics.

Capacity Building & Sustainability With Local School District Partners Our partnership with the Los Angeles Unified School District (cabinet level, district, and site administrators, and teachers) was strengthened by also establishing a strong advisory board and developing partnering with their Linked Learning division.  These partnerships were both critical in supporting students' interests in CS/STEM and impactful with respect to helping us develop our  2021 NSF RPP Computational Thinking Pathways grant being funded. 

Impacts

The research generated from this grant will provide timely research on how CT is developed and how learning pathways can be leveraged in changing the educational trajectory of students in subjects like mathematics. Our successfully funded  RPP will generate impact both in terms of contributions to relevant and future CT/CS/STEM scholarship and education activities that could make our RPP between a middle school, high school, and university-based research center scalable in other communities with similar racial and economic characteristics. 

 

 

 


Last Modified: 10/08/2021
Modified by: Tyrone C Howard
